Table of Contents

Enum RuleOperator

Namespace
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums
Assembly
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll

Defines the comparison operators available for evaluating conditions in the RSS reader's rule/filter engine.

public enum RuleOperator

Fields

Between = 11

The target field value falls within the specified inclusive range (minimum to maximum).

Behavior:

  • Requires two values: minimum and maximum (inclusive).
  • Works with numeric values (article length, word count, etc.).
  • Works with date/time values (publication date, last updated, etc.).
  • For strings, uses lexical/alphabetical comparison (rarely used).
  • Example: WordCount Between 500 and 1000 matches articles with 500-1000 words.
  • Example: Published Between "2025-01-01" and "2025-01-31" matches January 2025 articles.

Implementation notes:

  • Both values are required; UI should enforce min ≤ max.
  • Parsing failures should fail the condition gracefully (returns false).
  • For dates, consider timezone handling (typically UTC).
  • Inclusive boundaries: value ≥ min AND value ≤ max.
Contains = 0

The target field contains the specified substring (case-insensitive by default).

Behavior:

  • Partial text match anywhere in the field.
  • Most frequently used operator for keyword-based rules.
  • Example: Title Contains "breaking" matches "Breaking News Today".
EndsWith = 3

The target field ends with the specified suffix.

Behavior:

  • Checks only the end of the string.
  • Common for file extensions, URL patterns, or title endings.
Equals = 1

The target field exactly matches the specified value (case-insensitive by default).

Behavior:

  • Full exact match required (no wildcards).
  • Ideal for precise filters (author name, exact tag, specific title).
GreaterThan = 7

The target field (parsed as date or number) is greater than the specified value.

Behavior:

  • Used primarily for publication dates (e.g., newer than X days ago).
  • Requires field to be convertible to DateTime or numeric type.
  • Example: Published > "2025-01-01"
IsEmpty = 9

The target field is empty, null, or contains only whitespace.

Behavior:

  • Does not use comparison value.
  • Useful for detecting missing metadata (e.g., no author, empty content).
IsNotEmpty = 10

The target field is NOT empty (has content beyond whitespace).

Behavior:

  • Negation of IsEmpty.
  • Common for ensuring field presence before other conditions.
LessThan = 8

The target field (parsed as date or number) is less than the specified value.

Behavior:

  • Used for older content (e.g., older than 7 days).
  • Same parsing requirements as GreaterThan.
NotBetween = 12

The target field value falls outside the specified inclusive range (less than minimum OR greater than maximum).

Behavior:

  • Negation of Between.
  • Requires two values: minimum and maximum (inclusive).
  • Matches if value is less than minimum OR greater than maximum.
  • Useful for outliers, old articles, or extremely long content.
  • Example: WordCount NotBetween 100 and 1000 matches very short or very long articles.

Implementation notes:

  • Both values are required; UI should enforce min ≤ max.
  • Same parsing requirements as Between.
  • Edge case: If min == max, this matches everything except that exact value.
NotContains = 4

The target field does NOT contain the specified substring.

Behavior:

  • Negation of Contains.
  • Useful for exclusion rules (e.g., ignore promotional content).
NotEquals = 5

The target field is NOT exactly equal to the specified value.

Behavior:

  • Negation of Equals.
  • Helps exclude specific known values.
Regex = 6

The target field matches the provided regular expression pattern.

Behavior:

  • Full regex matching (case sensitivity depends on implementation/flags).
  • Most powerful but slowest and most error-prone operator.
  • Requires validation of regex syntax in UI.
  • Example: \b[A-Z]{3}-\d{4}\b for codes like ABC-1234.
StartsWith = 2

The target field begins with the specified prefix.

Behavior:

  • Checks only the start of the string.
  • Useful for patterns like titles starting with "[Update]", "[Video]", etc.

Remarks

This enumeration specifies how a rule condition compares the value of a target field (title, content, author, etc.) against the user-provided value or pattern. The operator determines the matching logic applied during article evaluation.

Key considerations for operator selection and behavior:

  • String-based operators (Contains, Equals, etc.) are typically case-insensitive by default (configurable per rule or globally).
  • Numeric/date operators (GreaterThan, LessThan) are only valid when the target field is a date, numeric value, or can be parsed as such (e.g., publication date).
  • Regex supports full regular expression patterns (PCRE or .NET flavor, depending on implementation).
  • IsEmpty and IsNotEmpty ignore the comparison value and check field presence/content length.
  • Operators are evaluated per condition; multiple conditions in a rule use logical AND/OR grouping.

Business rules and usage recommendations:

  • Most common operators for keyword rules: Contains (broad) and Regex (precise).
  • Use Equals for exact matches (e.g., author name, specific category/tag).
  • StartsWith and EndsWith are useful for domain-specific patterns (e.g., titles starting with "[Sponsored]", URLs ending in ".pdf").
  • Date-based operators (GreaterThan, LessThan) require the field to be parsed as DateTimeOffset or similar; invalid parsing should fail the condition gracefully.
  • NotContains and NotEquals are useful for exclusion rules (e.g., "do not star articles containing 'ad' or 'promo'").
  • Between and NotBetween are ideal for range-based filtering (e.g., word count ranges, date ranges).
  • UI validation: Disable invalid operators for certain field types (e.g., hide date operators when target is Title/Content).
  • Performance note: Regex and full-text searches can be expensive on large datasets; use judiciously and prefer simpler operators when possible.
